Habitat.Distribution: Extinct, native to the island of Mauritius

PhysicalTraits.Color: Grayish-blue plumage, yellow beak with a black tip, yellow legs
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Unknown, estimated to be around 10-20 years in the wild, similar to large pigeons or doves.

Behavior.SocialType: Estimated solitary or in small family groups
Behavior.IntelligenceLevel: Unknown, likely limited due to lack of predators
Behavior.Communication: Unknown, likely vocalizations such as squawks or coos

Reproduction.GestationPeriod: Eggs incubated by both parents, estimated around 25-30 days
Reproduction.ReproductionCycle: Estimated once a year, likely during the wet season

Threats: Habitat loss due to human settlement
Hunting by humans and introduced animals (pigs, macaque monkeys, rats)

HumanInteraction.Notes: Species has gone extinct due to human activity and introduced species around the late 17th century.

FunFacts: Became a symbol of extinction due to human impact.
Its name might derive from the Dutch word 'dodoor' meaning 'sluggard' or 'lazy'.

Habitat.Distribution: Extinct, formerly widespread across Eurasia and North America

PhysicalTraits.Size: Males approximately 9-11 feet (2.7-3.4 meters) tall at the shoulder; females slightly smaller
PhysicalTraits.Color: Dark brown or black long fur, varied depending on individual and preservation
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Estimated 60-70 years, similar to modern elephants
SpecialTraits: Small ears to minimize heat loss

Foods: Estimated mosses and other vegetation found in steppe-tundra environments

Reproduction.MaturityAge: Unknown, estimated around 10-15 years, similar to modern elephants
Reproduction.GestationPeriod: Estimated 22 months, similar to modern elephants
Reproduction.ReproductionCycle: Estimated every 3-4 years, similar to modern elephants

Threats: Climate change (warming leading to habitat loss and fragmentation)
Overhunting by early humans

HumanInteraction.Notes: Last known populations died out around 4,000 years ago on Wrangel Island.

FunFacts: Closest living relatives are Asian elephants.
Their remains are often found well-preserved in permafrost.

Habitat.Distribution: Extinct, formerly widespread across eastern North America

PhysicalTraits.Color: Males: slate blue head and neck, reddish-orange breast; Females: duller, more brownish
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Unknown, estimated 10-15 years, similar to other large pigeons

Behavior.SocialType: Highly colonial, lived in immense flocks and nesting colonies
Behavior.IntelligenceLevel: Unknown, likely social intelligence due to flocking behavior
Behavior.Communication: Various cooing sounds, wing clapping during flight

Reproduction.ReproductionCycle: Estimated 1-2 clutches per year, often synchronized within colonies

Threats: Massive commercial hunting (for meat and feathers)
Habitat destruction (deforestation of breeding grounds)

HumanInteraction.Notes: Once the most numerous bird in North America, its extinction was rapid and complete by the early 20th century (last individual died in 1914).

FunFacts: Their flocks were so vast they could darken the sky for hours.
Their extinction is a prime example of human-induced extinction.

Habitat.Distribution: Extinct, formerly native to Australia and New Guinea, most recently confined to Tasmania

PhysicalTraits.Size: Approximately 3.3-4.3 feet (1-1.3 meters) long (head to tail base), plus a tail of 20-26 inches (50-65 cm)
PhysicalTraits.Color: Yellowish-brown fur with distinctive dark stripes on its back and tail base
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Unknown, estimated 5-7 years in the wild, up to 9 years in captivity

Foods: Kangaroo rats and other small rodents
Estimated sheep and poultry after European settlement

Reproduction.GestationPeriod: Estimated 35 days (marsupial, young develop in pouch)
Reproduction.OffspringPerBirth: Typically 2-4 young (joeys) born underdeveloped and mature in a pouch

Threats: Intensive hunting (bounty system by settlers)
Habitat loss and fragmentation
Disease
Competition with dingoes and wild dogs

HumanInteraction.Notes: The last known Tasmanian Tiger died in Hobart Zoo in 1936. There have been unconfirmed sightings since.

FunFacts: Despite its common name, it was a marsupial, not a true tiger or wolf.
Had a distinctive stiff tail, tapering from the body.

Habitat.Environment: North Atlantic coastal waters, rocky islands
Habitat.Distribution: Extinct, formerly found in the North Atlantic Ocean

PhysicalTraits.Color: Black back and head, white belly, white patch below each eye
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Unknown, estimated 20-30 years, similar to other long-lived seabirds

Behavior.SocialType: Colonial breeder, highly social during breeding season

Reproduction.MaturityAge: Unknown, estimated 3-5 years, similar to other large seabirds
Reproduction.ReproductionCycle: Annual breeding in large, dense colonies on remote islands

Threats: Intensive hunting (for meat, eggs, feathers, oil)
Vulnerability due to flightlessness and breeding in accessible colonies

HumanInteraction.Notes: The last confirmed pair was killed on Eldey Island, Iceland, in 1844.

FunFacts: Often referred to as the 'penguin of the north' due to similar appearance and ecological niche.
Their flightlessness made them easy prey for hunters.

Classification.Species: E. quagga quagga (subspecies of Plains Zebra)

PhysicalTraits.Size: Estimated 8.2-8.5 feet (2.5-2.6 meters) long, 4.1-4.7 feet (1.25-1.45 meters) tall at shoulder
PhysicalTraits.Color: Brownish-red with zebra-like stripes on the front half of the body, fading to solid brown on the rear
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Unknown, estimated 20-30 years, similar to other equids

Behavior.SocialType: Herd animals (Estimated, similar to other zebras)
Behavior.Communication: Various vocalizations, including a distinctive 'kwa-ha' sound (hence the name 'quagga'), neighs, snorts

Reproduction.MaturityAge: Unknown, estimated 2-3 years, similar to zebras

Threats: Extensive hunting by European settlers for meat and hides
Competition with livestock for grazing land

HumanInteraction.Notes: The last wild quagga was likely killed in the late 1870s; the last captive individual died in Amsterdam Zoo in 1883. The Quagga Project is attempting to breed back quaggas through selective breeding of plains zebras.

FunFacts: Was once considered a distinct species, but genetic studies confirmed it as a subspecies of the plains zebra.
Its unique striping pattern made it easily recognizable.

Habitat.Distribution: Extinct in the wild (possibly functionally extinct), formerly found in the Yangtze River in China
Countries: China (Yangtze River) (Extinct in the Wild/Functionally Extinct)

PhysicalTraits.Color: Light blue-gray with a white belly
SpecialTraits: Long, slender beak with many teeth

Behavior.ActivityTime: Diurnal and Nocturnal (Estimated, based on other river dolphins)
Behavior.SocialType: Estimated solitary or in small groups (2-3 individuals)

Threats: Intensive fishing (bycatch in fishing gear, especially rolling hooks)
Habitat degradation (pollution, dam construction, river traffic, sand dredging)

HumanInteraction.Notes: A survey in 2006 found no individuals, leading to its declaration as functionally extinct. It is considered the first cetacean to be driven to extinction by human activity.

FunFacts: Known as the 'Goddess of the Yangtze' in China.
Its eyesight was very poor, relying heavily on echolocation in the murky river.

Habitat.Distribution: Extinct, formerly found in the North Pacific Ocean, particularly around the Bering Sea

PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Unknown, estimated around 50 years, similar to other large long-lived marine mammals
SpecialTraits: No teeth, used horny plates for chewing

Behavior.SocialType: Estimated lived in small family groups
Behavior.IntelligenceLevel: Unknown, likely typical for large marine herbivores

Reproduction.MaturityAge: Unknown, estimated 5-7 years, similar to other sirenians

Threats: Intensive hunting by Russian fur traders and explorers for meat, blubber, and hide
Ease of capture due to its large size, slow movement, and fearlessness of humans

HumanInteraction.Notes: Discovered in 1741 and hunted to extinction within 27 years, by 1768. It was completely defenseless against human hunters.

FunFacts: Named after Georg Steller, the naturalist who first described it.
Could not fully submerge, making it an easy target for hunters.

Habitat.Environment: Coastal waters, sandy beaches, rocky islets, coral reefs
Habitat.Distribution: Extinct, formerly found throughout the Caribbean Sea, Gulf of Mexico, and western Atlantic Ocean

PhysicalTraits.Color: Brownish-gray on the back, lighter yellow-brown on the belly
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Unknown, estimated 20-25 years, similar to other monk seals
SpecialTraits: Only seal native to the Caribbean Sea
Docile and not fearful of humans

Behavior.SocialType: Estimated solitary or in small groups on haul-out sites
Behavior.Communication: Unknown, likely various barks and grunts (Estimated)

Threats: Intensive hunting for blubber (oil), meat, and hide
Overfishing of their prey base
Disturbance of breeding and resting sites by human activity

HumanInteraction.Notes: Declared extinct in 2008 by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, though the last confirmed sighting was in 1952.

FunFacts: The only seal species endemic to the Caribbean Sea.
Their docile nature made them very vulnerable to human exploitation.

Habitat.Distribution: Extinct, native to Pinta Island in the Galápagos archipelago

PhysicalTraits.Size: Estimated up to 3 feet (0.9 meters) shell length
PhysicalTraits.Lifespan: Unknown, estimated well over 100 years, typical for giant tortoises
SpecialTraits: Long neck for reaching high vegetation

Behavior.SocialType: Solitary (Estimated, typical for giant tortoises), occasionally congregate around water sources
Behavior.IntelligenceLevel: Unknown, likely basic problem-solving for foraging

Reproduction.MaturityAge: Unknown, estimated 15-20 years, typical for giant tortoises

Threats: Overhunting by sailors and whalers for food
Introduction of non-native species (goats, rats) that degraded habitat and preyed on eggs/hatchlings

HumanInteraction.Notes: The last known individual, 'Lonesome George,' died in 2012, marking the extinction of the species. Efforts were made to breed him, but they were unsuccessful.

FunFacts: Lonesome George became a global symbol of conservation.
Their saddleback shell allowed them to browse higher vegetation on arid islands.
